title: What are the things on Neeko's head?
body:
Are they organic? Plants like her hair flowers? Little feelers?

If there's not an answer out there, I'd like to imagine they're how she senses peoples "sho'ma" , kinda like dowsing rods.

replies.body:
They're actually beautiful glands, like the pinneal gland, which allow Neeko to sense and interact with people's Sho'Ma. I read a lot of esoteric magic ideas whenever I have to write champs that are inherently magical. The theory that organic, physical parts of the body are made to touch, sense, and manipulate the magic/spirit energies is intensely fascinating to me, from a fictional perspective. 

One idea I loved reading that is that unicorns symbolize magic because humans used to have a pineal gland that stuck out of our foreheads, but as we evolved over time, the glad retracted into our heads to become the "third eye". I doubt it's true at all, but ideas like this make me happy. It's fun to apply that sort of logic to entities like the vastaya who are on their own wild evolutionary timeline.

I doubt it's true at all, but ideas like this make me happy. It's fun to apply that sort of logic to entities like the vastaya who are on their own wild evolutionary timeline.

The penal gland is hooked up to an actual third eye in some reptiles and amphibians, most notably in the tuatara.  It's mostly just a light-sensitive organ that's used for various regulatory cycles.  Though in some salamanders it appears to be able to detect polarized light, which is useful for tracking the sun's position (again, to help with regulatory cycles).

Basically yeah, third eye is a real thing.  But its function is way more boring than suggested by parapsychology.  That's science for you.

Correct! The truth is so boring that people extrapolate far-flung, esoteric notions of biology. Check out Mark Booth's Secret History of the World for more "information" about pseudo sciences, esoteric thought, mystery schools, and new age cosmology. It's a weird primer that tries to wrap everything in history into a single world narrative. It's fun, if not batshit.
